unnormalised: So, someone asked how safe are online payments in India? Well, let me tell you, it's about as safe as riding a scooter in Delhi during peak hours - exciting, but you gotta be alert!
normalised: So, someone asked how safe are online payments in India? Well, let me tell you, it's about as safe as riding a scooter in Delhi during peak hours - exciting, but you gotta be alert!

unnormalised: Seriously though, making online payments thru apps like Paytm, GPay, PhonePe is pretty common now, right? I mean, who carries cash anymore? It's all digital these days. But with great convenience comes great responsibility... and a bunch of scammers trying to get their mitts on your hard-earned ₹₹.

unnormalised: First off, always, always, ALWAYS check the website or app is legit before you enter any details. Look for that little padlock icon in the address bar, and make sure the URL starts with "https". If it's just "http", run away! Faster than you would from a relative trying to set you up with their neighbour's cousin's daughter. Also, avoid clicking on links sent via SMS or email – those are usually traps! It’s like accepting free chole bhature from a roadside stall; tempting, but you might regret it later.

Look for that little padlock icon in the address bar, and make sure the U-R-L starts with "H-T-T-P-S". If it's just "H-T-T-P", run away! Faster than you would from a relative trying to set you up with their neighbor's cousin's daughter. Also, avoid clicking on links sent via S-M-S or email – those are usually traps! It's like accepting free chole bhature from a roadside stall; tempting, but you might regret it later.

unnormalised: And for the love of all things holy, set strong passwords! "Password123" or your pet's name aren’t going to cut it. Think random combinations of letters, numbers, and symbols. Also, enable 2FA (Two-Factor Authentication) whenever possible. It’s like having a security guard for your ₹150000 bank account. If someone tries to hack in, they'll need a special code sent to your phone. Bonus points if your phone also has a fingerprint lock.

If someone tries to hack in, they'll need a special code sent to your phone. Bonus points if your phone also has a fingerprint lock.

unnormalised: Finally, keep an eye on your bank statements. Regularly. Report any suspicious transactions immediately. It’s better to be safe than sorry and end up explaining to your family why all your hard earned ₹10000 savings disappeared overnight. You don't want to be the person who funded some scammer's lavish Goa vacation. Trust me.
